THE GOSPEL (updated)   Hello guys! May I have your attention even for just a second? this might take awhile btw haha-(this will get long)  I would like to share something to all of you, feel free to read what I have to say,  whether you may read this or not it is your free will if you will stay, but if you wish to leave then go ahead and do so,  I am in NO way, shape or form trying to force this unto anyone, just scroll down if you dislike or feel offended of this.   However, if you do, it IS and can be a missed opportunity to know more about this topic of truth. I am not forcing you to stay, for I am quite aware that many of you may have had a very bad experience with people sharing their belief or ideology in the past.  On behalf of those people, whoever they may be, I truly apologize, I'm just trying to create a safe space for every person, mentally, physically, spiritually and emotionally.  But even so, try to listen, even for just a bit :)  The Gospel is free to absolutely everyone, no matter what religion, race or background etc. you may have been in.  Everyone is welcome to accept this free gift :D  Anyways, let's start!  -------  Sin was passed upon all men by one man  Adam, and death is a consequence of this sin  (Rom 5:12).   Mankind has an eternal destiny of  condemnation and wrath â€“ Hell â€“ because of  this sin (Rom 6:23).   No matter what good  works one might do we are still found sinners in the sight of our Creator God.   And all un righteous and those who follow get His wrath.  BECAUSE We cannot be found  Righteous for by Godâ€™s law we are found sinners (Rom 3:19-20).  If we have broken even one law we are found guilty.  Just a simple curse, a roll of an eye, a lustful look or even just by being ourselves, is already subjected to Hell fire, because no matter what we do this isn't at all worthy of anything, even our own good are compared to filthy rags.  (Isaiah 64:6)  That is also why the LAW is there to STOP our mouths for us to REALIZE we can NEVER do it. (Romans 3:19)  Now because of this reason of not being able to  create our own righteousness and being born  in a sinful flesh that we need a SAVIOR (Titus 3:5).   Now on to the GOSPEL.   That savior is Jesus Christ.  Salvation was finished and DONE by HIM and every ounce of our salvation RESTS ONLY BY HIS SACRIFICE. Once we trust He saved us, gave us eternal life, reconciled us by HIS blood, we are SEALED by the Holy spirit of promise, till the day of redemption. (Ephesians 4:30)  THEN HE LEADS us to our purposes of righteous practical living, based on OUR NEW identity in Christ , as REASONABLE service and NOT to "work our way to salvation"(because remember, there is NON good but GOD(Mark 10:18) but to simply act as God's children, because HE LOVED US SO MUCH that Jesus died for us.  That's the service we can give because of such an impact JESUS did WILLINGLY, it is our gratitude and not an act of trying to earn what we can NEVER achieve.   It is a FREE GIFT(Romans 6:23) afterall, you can't earn a gift, because that wouldn't be a gift anymore, but a reward, and remember, Jesus dying is not worthy of any of us, we do not DESERVE such a great sacrifice, that is why you also can't earn salvation on your own, because we just CAN NEVER do it.   And Jesus died EXACTLY for ALL of that, because He loves us too much.   This simple Gospel message is also in:  1 Corinthians 15:1-4 King James Version(for a more simple summary)  "15 Moreover, brethren, I declare unto you the gospel which I preached unto you, which also ye have received, and wherein ye stand;  2 By which also ye are saved, if ye keep in memory what I preached unto you, unless ye have believed in vain.  3 For I delivered unto you first of all that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures;  4 And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day according to the scriptures"  NOTHING added to it because it's JUST THAT SIMPLE! :D  There's more about the Gospel out there that I highly suggest, like Renee Roland for further assurance and Mark Dejesus for the psychological aspects of being a Christian.  Anyways that's it! if you made it till the end, than I am HIGHLY grateful for giving me this chance to share to you!  God bless and TAKE CARE! <3   (idk I'm just so passionate about this because so little so few people know the simple message of the Gospel of Christ, or even take it seriously at that T^T thanks so much for reading tho! Maybe you can't tell by my profile picture, but I'm 23 now as of a couple of days ago, and I've been struggling with the idea of getting older lately, especially letting go of these friendships I once had... Honestly the past few years I've been denying that me and my once best friend might not ever be as close as we once were, even if we both wanted to. People change, people grow apart. I wish I could say that once you realize that, it's easy to move on... But I think that part of coming to terms with bittersweet situations is accepting what you can't change, and accepting the feelings you have right now. I like what Anthony said about letting go of the idea of what your relationship with someone you care about *should* be, and basically coming to terms with what it is. Even though I'm still sad, it gives me comfort knowing that it is possible to move forward and to know that other people have had similar experiences

57:32 Wow, Joshua Wolf Shenk's theory of innovation in creative partnerships in evidence! His argument is that the most successful duos have intense commonalities that inspire and excite each other, but also operate in different ways that end up completing each other and making great work possible; one such interaction is the "liquid" partner (pouring out creative ideas) and the "container" partner (catches and shapes and gives the best form to the ideas with intense focus); sounds like exactly what Anthony is describing of their dynamic

It's heartbreaking to see the difference in emotion between these two and how they converse during the video. Since his seperation, Anthony had time to declog all the emotional resentment he had for the company and was finally able to do his own creative thing. This interview was likely the first time he was able to lift those weights off personally to Ian. And it's why he was able to cry at the thought of remembering their first lunch together, and how he realized that his childhood bestfriend was still there. In the meantime, Ian was left to manage this big company all by himself; he went through Anthony's seperation, Defy medias abrupt collapse, being adopted by Rhett and Link, the rewriting of Smosh's brand, managing a team of talented people, and handling criticism from the public. I couldn't imagine just how much emotional baggage Ian had to carry that he had to seek a therapist. And he mentioned getting therapy in this video like it wasn't a big deal. But it was a big deal. Because Ian learned how to compartamentalize all his issues, he likely dealt with the emotional trauma a long time ago. Which is why, despite discussing all the things he went through in Smosh and with Anthony, that he got so used to not expressing his emotions. And its why we see him talk somewhat slower and emotionally un-phased in this interview. It's the image of a person who went through so much but still wants to put a smile on our faces. Though Anthony went through his fair share of struggles, I feel like Ian doesn't get enough credit whenever people talk about Smosh. And I think that's where the fans had it wrong - that Smosh wouldn't survive with just Ian in the picture.

I have been using YouTube as a source of joy and distraction for many many years of my life now and have come to have such respect for creators who do this, seemingly thanklessly. I look up to you all as a source of inspiration, yet I see the hilarity and fun and success and have found ways to feel bad about myself for not making my own joy like you have (from an outsider's perspective, it always looks so perfect). Despite intuitively knowing that you all are still just humans trying their best, it's too easy to put you on a pedestal when all we can see is the good stuff. This video and its deep honesty and vulnerability has seriously touched my soul. I'm at a place in my life where my identity and its dependence on my success and relationships is causing some pretty significant strife. Thank you so very much for proving that success and happiness don't always go hand-in-hand, and that it is never too late to have the conversations needed to repair relationships. You've lightened my heart and I appreciate it so much. Just writing this comment to put this newfound peace into words, out into the universe, is healing by itself. Congratulations on your individual journeys and on your bravery to come back together and start a new one! I'm rooting for you!

I've got a Interview suggestion, A Medical Disorder called Lack of Interoception or Alexithymia as I have researched. (If a person's Interoception is not fully developed, they may find it difficult to manage their emotions and social interactions. If someone does not recognize the signals for an emotion, they are not able to respond to it. This can result in anger becoming rage, sadness becoming distress and so on.) (Yes I copied that from Google.) Some others also cannot or almost cannot feel internal senses like the rest of the world. I currently have this Disorder or some form of it and I have never once seen another individual with my condition throughout the entire world.   MY Interoception is my internal senses like Hunger, Thirst, Bladder, and even Internal pain.   Internal Pain - My Internal pain I cannot feel pain like I would on the outside. I remember getting hit by a truck in my neighborhood in sixth grade and I just got up, Totally fine. I just told the driver that I was fine and walked on home, Never telling my parents. The only reason my parents knew was because the truck driver followed me home to make sure I was alright. I didn't tell my parents because I did not think it was a big deal at the time but It definitely was. My ribs were hurt in the process and all I did was put some ice on it.  Bladder - With My Bladder sense I could not feel the urge to go and use the bathroom resulting in a lot of accidents when I was younger. With this information I was wearing diapers up until around 10 - 11 years of age. I was potty trained and I am doing good with bladder now but I still have accidents every once in awhile.  Thirst - I cannot feel Thirst, Making me not take care of my thirst "Meter", Resulting in semi-constant headaches due to lack of hydration and fluid going into my body. Also causing me to get sick a lot.  Hunger - Hunger is something I cannot deny feeling left out when everyone else is saying "I'm hungry", I tend to just eat at the same time as others as to not miss my food time. I have almost developed eating disorders multiple times due to my lack of the hunger sense. Hunger also makes food seem more delicious when you're hungry making you want to eat while as when you are full, the food seems more bland and disgusting making you not want to eat it. I am constantly stuck in this mindset of deciding whether I should eat or not, whether eating is good for me at the moment or whether I am even supposed to eat then. I tend to have others force me to eat when they have noticed I haven't eaten for a long time period. I never know when I should stop eating or when I should eat.  I'm currently 13 years old turning 14 soon and still struggling with this. I have other conditions such as Autism, OCD, and ADHD which add-on to my condition. I've had Lack of Interoception since I was born.

I never got into "old Smosh" back in the day, but having found both this channel and the various Smosh channels in the past year I am so excited to see this friendship coming back together. I went on a similar journey with my best friend from high school, we didn't have a falling out but just went in very different directions after high school and drifted apart. I was pretty resigned to the idea that we just weren't going to be friends anymore, as sad as that was. Six years later, she randomly reached out to me saying that she had been thinking about me and realizing how much she missed our friendship, and we started talking again and now four years later are closer than we've ever been before. I honestly believe that we needed to be apart for some time to really figure ourselves out, sometimes you can go through those transitions with current friends but other times you need room from them to grow, while still recognizing that further on that friendship may be able to come back around. I'm so glad to see that you two have reconnected and are excited to move forward at Smosh together again. I can't wait to see what you do!

This interview is so bittersweet but it also brings me so much joy. I felt like I kind of grew up on Smosh as I watched it in my teenage years. So in a way it is really nostalgic and I'll always love the old content. But now being in my mid-twenties and seeing you both come together again makes me so excited to see how your comedy has evolved and to see how it will appeal to old and new fans. I can't wait to see what you both have planned!  But also, I want to touch on how good of an interview this is. I think it's so amazing that you two could sit down as adults and talk about the problems you had, and that you admit where you each had faults. And that you recognize how important that time apart and growth was, despite how difficult it may have been in the moment. Not to mention the fact it shows how realistic your friendship is and that it's not perfect. But it's real and it's genuine, and it's such a great example of how time and circumstances change people. I can't even imagine how difficult it is to have that kind of relationship scrutinized by the public and feel the weight of those expectations. But it really says a lot that you both were able to realize what you needed separately and that it allowed you both to grow so you could get to this point. It's so incredibly humanizing, and as someone who's currently on their own long and extensive journey to better myself and as someone who loved you two as a duo way back when it means a lot to me. It gives me hope that good things come and go, but change doesn't always have to be a bad thing because it can lead to something far more beautiful in the long run. ğŸ’™

That makes me genuinely emotional and makes me think of all the friends I've had in my life and how I love them all even if we haven't talked in years. We're all just people at the end of the day, and the connections we have with each other is more valuable than anything else. It seems Apples to Oranges, but comparing the professional/personal relationships displayed between Smosh and GMM are somewhat of a lesson in male friendship as well as partnered business management. Ian and Anthony were teens when they started receiving fame for their crude mid-2000s humor, this type of content spoke to the teens with their new iPods as well as widespread computers and WIFI filling up homes, Smosh quickly evolved into Obnoxious, loud Gen-Z shock humor. I remember being 7 and watching 2010 Smosh vids on our home computer as they came out, me and my brother loved all their shit, and it honestly, along with 100 other things in the coming years, influenced our senses of humor.   Rhett and Link started their channel with admittedly much better quality editing due to them already being mostly adults, They had been friends since Elementary and they grew up living near each other and spending their childhood as close companions, when they started YouTube in 2006 they made music videos with witty, knee-slapper lyrics, as well as slightly absurd millennial humor based skits, this type of content spoke to a similar demographic as Smosh as well as viewers 5-10 years older, However, i make this comparison because come 2012,  Smosh's content was on par with Rhett and Link's in terms of comedic value to their respective demographics.   When it came to displaying their friendships within commercializing their content and bringing on sponsorships and companies, Rhett and Link (being college educated) took control and started GMM, a separate channel with a mother company, fully preserving their original content, in this new space, it being a morning show, it was dedicated to talking and sharing interest, their years long and fully established friendship had no reason not to persist.   Anthony and Ian were in an environment built by their 15 year old personalities, forcing them to retain that sense with each other, regardless of how much time they spent together, it was never right to respect each other as genuine adult friends, since there was never any genuine emotional bonding shared within the roots of the friendship. It would be hard to expect literal kids to understand the importance of genuine conversation and emotional connection, especially two teenage boys laughing til their lungs hurt at a fart joke they're super proud of, and then eventually making money off similar jokes, for years on end  Personally I feel like there was potential for a genuine life-long friendship that was spoiled by 21st century media and the strive to nurture a business built on ideas you may no longer agree with or even find entertaining. (idk the full GMM situation nowadays, all this info is off the top of my head)
If it's love you let them go, if they come back that's how you know â¤ï¸

I started watching smosh (really just smosh pit) after Anthony left so I never knew him or had the nostalgia for old smosh, but this was so touching and I found myself tearing up, so happy for everything coming back full circle, and so happy to have Anthony rejoin Smosh at the helm with Ian <3
God you guys were such a huuuuge part of my entertainment growing up, I remember Towards Anthony leaving how crushing it was to start realizing things were going to different. Having you back is a desperately needed spark of joy in an otherwise grim and stressful world
Congrats you two! This makes my heart so happy for you and your team!  Listening to this was so nostalgic but it hurt my heart a little because I was one of those people that called Anthony "Smosh" after the split. (To be fair I hadn't watched Smosh in years.)  I was an editor for a growing YouTube channel that had recently been acquired by Defy. We got invited to the vidcon party on the industry floor, despite not being able to pay for industry passes, and I was overwhelmed! Looking around at this massive room of creators and celebrities, it felt like joining Defy meant that we had made it!   Then... Through the next year we started to see what Defy was up to, and it was not what we thought it was, and felt we were being taken advantage of.  The next year at vidcon, we were again invited to the Defy party... But this time it was tucked off in a small room to the side, and I'm going to be honest, it looked like a highschool group project. It was so confusing. And with some other things I had going on, I decided to slip away from everyone into a back hallway of the convention center.  It was just me alone in a hallway with my feelings, when Anthony, comes rushing past me. In the moment I couldn't remember his name so I just blurted "HEY SMOSH!" He stopped and whipped around and the pain that I saw in his face for that split second tore through me. He quickly put on a happy face and walked over and shook my hand and said to the tune of "Hey, I'm in a bit of a hurry, what's up" and I don't even remember what I said but it was a short thanking him for the years of content.   I'm weirdly glad to have had just that moment to thank at least half of Smosh for the years of content I watched growing up. No selfie, no autograph, just a moment of his time... I would later look Smosh up and realized Anthony was no longer part of Smosh... Oops.   If either of you somehow read this. Thank you for sitting down and doing this. I feel like a part of my childhood has now been reconnected! Plus this sets a good example for the next generation about making amends and taking things out, both of you are an inspiration!
I follow you guys since the beningign and i love how your styles evolved, like anthony is a modern emo y ian its full colors

i remember when youtube used to shows top 10 popular videos on their homepage at the bottom right, smosh was a regular there, along with nigahiga, jenna marbles, shane dawson, and rwj (=3).  a bit off topic and i really hate to be that guy, but goddamn now i miss old youtube.  - top 2 comments on top while the bottom are a bit random so you always see different kinds of comments - comments can actually get NEGATIVE likes and it'll show you - personalize channel page where you can upload a background, pick a color for the fonts and the square thing that i still dont know the name of (above the background but at the back of the fonts, basically like themes but you can only pick colors), and iirc even put someone else's video on your channel front page (bcs i could've sworn i put like a game trailer for my old account's page even though i was too dumb to know how to upload shit) - by today standard's all of the layout IS UGLY, but somehow felt more comfortable to look at, if that makes sense - people can leave a comment on your channel, and it'll be easy to find (like steam basically) - inboxes, though i only ever used it once to argue with someone - you can click on any videos, and keep clicking on the suggestion bar, and end up on some weirdest shit that you'll never find on today's youtube (because the suggestion bar actually ONLY shows videos that are related to the video that you're watching, not filled with videos from people you subscribed to with some 1-2 related videos)  very sad i forgot my password to my old account that uploaded copyrighted trailers for the game Dogz and Catz, its a part of a history. the "broadcast yourself" era when the "tube" is still in the red square will always be my favorite. smosh's reunion brings back memories

They forget to mention but they were offer Stocks while there was little to no internet back then. The best info you can get was from the library or an actual business professional.
What some people forget about is youtube was a new concept at the time. Now we have proven record of people making career out of it for multiple years, but back then? Nobody knew what was going to happen. And their were multiple case of people shooting in subscriptions due to one viral video and losing that momentum right after. So I see why Ian thought it was a good idea at the time.

I don't think people understand how unique this relationship is AND how amazing this reunion is.  Imagine you're best friend from high school that you grew away from. You know the one, we all have them. Instead of growing apart, you go into business together after high-school. You create something huge, you live together, you throw yourselves into this work. But... The magic of the friendship starts to burn out. You're more coworkers then you are friends. All their memories remain hit the friendship just isn't there. Eventually one of you leaves, and the company starts to falter. Instead, you both pick yourselves up and go in new directions. You are successful, but not together. Then somehow, someway the universe allows you to meet again AND reclaim that business and friendship.  Its genuinely amazing how this all worked out.

When I was 12/13 my buddy and I we're massive Smosh fans. At sleepovers we used to watch the videos on repeat late at night in our basements, trying desperately to contain our laughter so our parents wouldn't wake up and give us hell. Eventually this evolved into trying to make our own "comedy" skits. Filming with a shitty digital camera, we howled with laughter trying to think up new scenes and lines. When we finally finished we would grab some Tim Hortons or something and my buddy would attentively edit the clips for hours on end in Windows Movie Maker while I peered over his shoulder eating a doughnut. Even though the videos were obviously terrible and unfunny, I'll still never forget the bond and incredible optimism and excitement for the future that came from working on and creating something together. I'll always remember feeling this kind of sudden self awareness that we were very young and that that meant the future could hold quite literally anything for us. What a profound feeling to recognize that we were just starting to explore the galaxy of life ahead.   We had a pretty bad falling out somewhere in our late teens, and we hated each other for a while. It was over a girl or something, the sad thing is that I honestly can't fully remember. It was genuinely harder for me than any breakup I've been through. He was the best friend I ever had.   As I've grown older, I haven't really paid much attention to anything Smosh for years , but this video had me smiling like crazy. Like an insane amount. I even felt the same sort of childhood joy I felt back then with my buddy. It's nice to see two people who were once extremely close but have drifted apart find each other again and newly discover the things that made them such close friends in the first place. It gives me hope that maybe one day me and my old best friend can reconnect. Maybe we'll even make a sketch.
Good to see that you two are doing better. I think this is a great thing for the new generation to see too. Thanks for uploading this sensitive video!

This interview had everything I ever wanted. For the longest time, as an oblivious naive kid, I always wondered how and why those things happened at Smosh. Especially with what had happened between Anthony and Ian. When Anthony announced he was leaving, I just didn't get it. I was left with so many questions. I wasn't very socially acclimated, and I didn't really understand how these businesses worked.  Fast forward through the years to last July, when Anthony was a guest on the Trash Taste podcast, he discussed their upbringing during the early Smosh days, and his experiences and gripes with Defy media, and why he ultimately left. I came out of that video with a new perspective on everything. Yet, I still had questions about the relationship of what had happened between Anthony and Ian. And man, this video delivered. Them being as vulnerable and as transparent as they were here, legitimately got me teary eyed for a moment. Not only was I graced with the nostalgia of them just simply, being together on camera, once again --but watching them discuss how they broke the ice about everything that happened between them was just so moving. As dudes, I feel like we often do a bad job at communicating transparently amongst each other, on certain things, and they showed us just that.   I'm glad you guys are close again :)

I have been really, really hoping this would happen for years now but I have a lot of concerns. I have been a fan of Classic Smosh for over a decade. While the interview alleviated many of them. I have watched way too much YouTube since around 2008 and seen many channels rise fall. These are some of the biggest concerns I still have:  1. The new cast members being forced into the videos. I watched your videos because I wanted to see Ian and Anthony. I have never watched a video because I wanted to see Shawn or Courtney or any of the other cast members. I am back because Anthony and Ian are back together. This is the case for most of your fans of else your current views wouldn't be so much lower than your classic views. I don't mind if they are in there if they do it well and it is truly an Ian and Anthony video but, when I watch an Ian and Anthony video on the main Smosh channel. I want it to be a true to form Ian and Anthony video. I think this is by far the biggest concern I and most other fans have. I am worried that you two, Ian in particular, will have trouble doing this since you've known them for years and they're your friends and employees but please make this work.  2. Memberships. I just want you two to know that I, and some other fans, will be waiting a few months to see if this actually works or if it is just hot trash. If it actually works, I will definitely join and get a membership. I believe that many others will be in the same boat  3. Selling out. You guys sold out before and it didn't work out. A lot of the business stuff and the administration stuff or whatever that caused you to sell out can't have changed a lot or gone away in the last decade. What are you guys going to do when faced with this challenges again? I don't want you guys to sell out again or give up. I have never seen a channel that doesn't go to garbage after selling out and I have watched YouTube for over 15 years. I don't know if you two can handle it now or you have some sort of strategy to deal with it but I want to mention how a channel called Linus Tech Tips that has multiple side channels and millions of subscribers handled it. Essentially, they just hired on a new CEO to handle all of the Business Administration stuff while the original channel owner and his wife still own the channel and the company so he can focus on making videos and still have the final say over all of the important stuff. This happened recently so if this approach is going to fail or not hasn't been decided but it seems like the best way of handling the situation that I have seen from any youtuber. Please don't sell out again.  That's it. I really, really hope this works out.    P.s. If it does, can you get the original Amish games cast back plus Wes and Flitz. That would be great

Hello Anthony! If you ever manage to see this comment could you please spend a day with women with PCOS?? It's a syndrome that causes more male hormones in the female body along with other things as well causing woman to grow weight and even facial hair! A lot of women including myself have this and ever since I was a kid I've had many hardships finding others that also have this or knowing that others have this making us feel alone in a struggle with something we can't treat. Maybe a video of women with it could spread more awareness that there are others out there that feel our pain and know that there are others out there that also work through it.  From experience PCOS has caused bullying through my years of schooling because of facial hair and other places like legs, arms, stomach that grow hair and I was often bullied because of it. Some of my own family even went out of their way to say I'd never find love or get married because of something that is harder to control as a kid. I hope you find this and help share with the world that we aren't monsters! We're humans too!   Thank you!

Thank you both for this video. Having grown up on Smosh, it was always a heavy focus on the content side, with little regard to the logistics or the thoughts of those running it. When you think of Smosh, you don't really think about raged out office parties fueled by dying hopes and dreams. You think of Food Battle and If Video Games Were Real. Hearing these stories, the openness about the real side of things, it makes it feel more human. It helps you really appreciate this thing for what it is, and the long emotional journey it was getting to this point. This means so much to me. Smosh is the staple of my childhood, AND my bestfriend during childhood. We became bestfriends, ironically in a very similar fashion Ian and Anthony did. We were paired for a project in fourth grade, where we had to create a skit together that had a theme chosen for us. The theme we were given was "birthday party." As we worked on it, we got to know eachother better and realised how alike we were in tastes of just about everything, and we were just goofing around the entire class. We decided we needed to really crack down on this project in order to get it done, so he asked if I wanted to hang out after school. Me saying yes was the beginning of our long-term friendship. He introduced me to Smosh in probably 2011-2012 era, and that was the beginning of my Smosh era. I watched all the older videos too, and realised they weren't just famous youtubers for the whole world to see, but just two idiots in front of a camera for me and my own bestfriend to see and really relate to. We subconsciously started acting like Ian and Anthony. When we had sleepovers, we would wake up and go to my toy room and watch the old music videos like Firetruck and Parents Suck. We blasted the songs on my speakers and just pretended we were actually in the videos. Smosh has no idea how important these videos were for me and my best friend.  Flash forward a couple years, me and the friend aren't talking anymore. But I'm still watching Smosh, however, Smosh started to change too. Eventually, Anthony left and a bunch of new people were introduced. I just remembered feeling angry and empty. First my bestest friend ever leaves, now Ian's bestest friend leaves. It really played into how me and my friend and I emulated these guys.   More years later, me and this friend are now both 20 years old, and I decided to get in contact with him on facebook. We both apologized and have moved on. However, our friendship is no longer the same, and he has other friends he considers his bestfriend now. I guess I can't blame him, it's been a few years. But, at the same time, it hurts.   So, to say that Anthony coming back has patched SOMETHING up from that time period, is saying the least. I just hope that their comeback this time is done with a better mindset, and better support. These guys created a whole world of imagination for me that stays with me till this day.   My friend just turned 21, and I'm turning 21 this year, too.   If any child is reading any of this, keep your bestfriends close to you for as long as you can, and always communicate about what's bothering you. Never sweep things under the rug when someone is that close of a friend to you that they call themselves family.  Because that's what I used to have.

Wow, I remember that first lip sync video. At the time I thought it was funny, but I ended up not subscribing because I felt like the humor in general was very immature. We are around the same age, so I was looking at smosh as my peers, not really noticing the ways in which I was immature which were different but there none the less. Now, all these years later, to see both Anthony and Ian speak in such a mature, self aware way... It makes me feel weirdly proud of all of us? Like, wow, look at all that growing up we did! I think so often on social media I see people who don't grow up, who refuse to change, to reflect, to try and do better. It feels weirdly homey and nostalgic to look at these men, see them developed into such lovely people, and to look at myself and see all the growing I've done, and then to say "wow, after all that time we're all still here, being the best version of who we were meant to be." I'm genuinely looking forward to what comes next. It's nice to know that in some ways, the internet of my memories grew up with me.

Goes to show the differences between being under toxic management in a toxic work environment and a positive employer and ethically run company. Defy was too corporate, and mythical has ALWAYS given greater opportunity to their staff that show creativity. Bad employers push out content for money, and expect employees to change themselves "for the brand" and overwork their employees. Good companies let their employees flourish, give out promotions, opportunity and genuinely care about their employees careers progressing. Good youtbers care about their audiences and providing happy moments and entertainment that they'd enjoy themselves, not pandering algorithmic fodder for children.

It wasn't until I got older and grew into myself that I understood why. Both Anthony and Ian are around 10 years older than me. The sense of humor the two of them displayed resonated with me on a level I couldn't understand at the time. Now that I've grown and begun to understand my feelings I understand why it affected me so much. The two of them gave off this vibe of being the older brothers I got to hang out with. I got to take part in their jokes and enjoy being around people who wanted to make me laugh as much as they wanted to make each other laugh. So when Anthony left Smosh I was graduating high school. It was almost poetic in the way it worked. It felt like one of my older brothers had to move on at the same time I did. So around the same time I left Smosh too in a way. Of course I watched videos here and there to support the guys who worked so hard to keep it alive but it just wasn't something I consumed as much. Now with Anthony back it's like my older brother moved back home in a way. But we're all older and more mature. We're still gonna have that same sense of humor but it's gonna feel new again. Instead of me following around my two older brothers I get to feel like I'm old enough to understand.

This is a historical moment for YouTube, and it's wonderfully poetic that it's just two friends talking about their relationship. Its not dramatic or hyperbolic, it's just an earnest moment about a friendship tied to a business, and the process of that separation and re-connection. It's truly heartwarming and fascinating having been a kid that watched you both as Smosh, and now seeing you both come together after a long and arduous journey as adults as I now also am. I feel nothing short of honored to witness this moment, as a lot of us audience members have also been through our own trials and tribulations- and I can't speak for everyone of course, but I have come a long way from who I was, and it gives me so much joy to see proof that people can change and grow, while still being true to who they are; to not punish ourselves for our mistakes, and to forgive ourselves for doing what we feel is right at any given moment, even if it seemed wrong to others. Thank you Anthony and Ian for doing what you do, never change, but ironically, keep changing, keep trying, and keep living, and I will do the same, no matter what comes my way. Hopefully, I will learn from the mistakes I make, and grow in ways i'd never expect, just as a lot of us never expected to see this video.

I remember when I first watched Smosh and it was just funny and it felt like the humor (at the time) just got you. It is DEFINITELY a product of its time (which in this case is not fully a bad thing imo) but there was a lot of it that was funny cause it understood what a dumbass teenager on the internet would find funny and it was great. As I grew older I fell out of watching Smosh, I think it was right around the buy out, Im pretty sure at least. I remember feeling like that charm was gone and they weren't funny anymore. Now they were just another cash grab YouTube channel that felt super safe. I remember hearing about the buy out years later and having that context really explained a lot. I remember when Anthony left, I thought Smosh was gonna end, I thought that era was just over and ran its course. So its crazy after all of that hell that both Anthony and Ian went through that NOW they can be free to make what they want again. Its no longer advertiser safe, just dumb fun and whatever they feel they want it to be. Honestly while I'm not into that kind of content anymore, I am EXTREMELY curious where its going and I wanna support it where I can. I'm glad you guys got this freedom again, it just sucks that it had to happen in such a fucky way.

Ian's point at 45:06 is right on the money about friendships in adulthood as we all mature, I feel that personally in my case. My best friend and I met at college and about 2yrs into our friendship we went through an extremely rough patch for an extended amount of time thanks to drama and trauma. We had to let go of that and take space for a while before we naturally reconnected and eventually talked through everything. Now we've been thick as thieves like never before. You can't force things in life and I've had to learn that time and time again, and hell, I'm only in my 20s. I've lost and regained relationships in my life and have learned that sometimes time and space will heal those wounds and bring reconciliation, and if it doesn't, it will bring peace of mind from letting go. I think what im realizing zoning out & of course looking from the outside in on their situation is. Anthony has always been the more Emotional Person & Ian has always been the more Intellectual.    It doesn't mean that Anthony isn't a deep thinker or Ian doesn't have emotions but as they grew it was clear that someone like Anthony who feels things so strongly & craves a sense of Freedom could not thrive in an environment where his creativity was being challenged/stifled/judged etc.  And Ian was able to push past or overlook Anthonys concerns/struggles because it simply wasn't as important to him at the time as keeping the momentum he thought he had in his career going. Plus as he said he still had some deeply set fears of letting go of something thats working (even if things were drastically changing from the beginning of Smosh)  I can see why they drifted apart honestly, & even though Smosh wasn't a huge part of my childhood like others im genuinely happy they got the chance to be open and say these things/reconnect. To answer 29:00, the staff at Defy probably got a smaller version of Smosh deal. They were probably salaried employees who were working unpaid overtime, and also had stock options. So the idea is that Defy would go public and they would be the "next" Facebook kinda deal. It's  a very common practice in start ups, and especially media start up type business. So the employees would be pissed if suddenly via email you lost your job. I've been on that end of the stick many times in my professional career.

I think a lot of the oldest fans understood, at least I did, it felt like some inner working was at play, and for some reason it felt like both of you weren't exactly the same. Not that it entails the new content being bad, new things can be good, but I could sense something was wrong with you both. Not that I want to sound like I know a lot, but I have been through a lot of personal things, traumas, mental issues, myself. Wasn't fair if other fans were lashing out, upset, but not their fault either, they were sad, it was just a series of unfortunate events that... well affected everyone. Cool that you're both back, and back together, wish you the best moving forward, and hopefully your friendship especially doesn't hit these rough patches again, it seems like it needed too, and was important that it did, because you came from it stronger, but hopefully for you both it doesn't happen again, or at least not to as huge of a degree. Not even for us the fans, your health, your friendship should come 1st, is more important than anything, any content you can do, because... not to sound cheesy, but friendship is important.

And if someone does, Anthony and the people he loves will always be there to protect him. In Anthony's case, he had Mykie around so he was able to grow comfortable expressing himself. I hope Ian finds that person for him.

SHUT UP!!  But no, this was actually a really cool thing to see after growing up with Smosh. I felt the tension with the later videos, but had nothing but questions after the end of the pairing. But at that point I knew that they needed the space. Whatever the falling out was, it was personal, and people needed to move on.  Distance is so very important and almost impossible to explain to someone special. When you stack relationships with the same person/group, for a very long time, it seems doomed to fail. Interesting corollary to one piece of this. During Starcraft 1's heyday, Nick "Tasteless" Plott, and Sean "Day9" Plott were both huge commentators in the scene. Both were casters for numerous tournaments. And they never once, I believe, ever casted together. Refused to. And they are per both of their accounts, very close, loving brothers. But it was so critical to both that they keep their distance and develop their own brand and identity, they never could allow themselves to be "The Plott Brothers". So I understand Anthony needing to create a complete break and separation from Smosh if he ever had any hope of developing his own identity.

Ian saying the main channel didn't feel like it had an identity for a long time I think resonates with a lot of people who became fans around the time Anthony left, such as myself. When I started watching smosh I pretty much exclusively watched the pit channel. The content there was more my style and the identity of the channel was more solid, and as the years went it only got better as shows and segments were created and became regular things, i.e. tntl, eioyi, stan vs. the internet, who meme'd it. That content felt like the core of the smosh brand, the bits people remembered most and the best memes came from there, whereas games and the main channel were more nebulous. it wasn't until just this past year with ex interviews, lets do this, and the reunion series that I actually started watching the main channel ( and i hope these wont be gone gone, just move them to pit!). Now with Anthony back and him and Ian seeming to have a clear idea of what they want to do with the channel I hope that question mark clears up for them and continues to build the brand without disrupting the flow that's been built over the last few years. Post-defy smosh has consistently put out some of the best content on youtube and they're one of the few channels that I not only watch consistently but look forward to their uploads. Wishing them the best and hopefully this moves the channel in a new (old?) direction. <3

Whenever anyone says "it's just business," my immediate response (at least in my head) is, "Thanks, Lord Beckett, now go down with your ship." Companies are just groups of people, and business is just group activities. Everything that a business does will always be personal to someone, at some point, because we're all *human* and, at its core, every business is made of *humans,* too. Anyone trying to keep business "impersonal" will always either fail, or turn themselves into aloof assholes to force that process. And neither of those options is good. For anyone doing any kind of business: *recognize* the humanity in it, account for that, and embrace it.

Shit, I remember discovering Smosh back in like 2007/2008 and eagerly awaiting each weekly episode. My family had some sloooooow satellite Internet that required me to buffer and load the entire video so I could play it all in one go without interruptions. Literally, 10 minute videos would take at least 20-30 minutes to load, and as long as an hour if the connection was being messed up by the weather. Needless to say, the set up to watch these videos was quite the ordeal but made each video that much more enjoyable. Life was simpler when I was an 8th grader.
